1. the fusion will change our relationship with the administration. The fusionwill move away the administration and the power from the local territory and centralizing it somwhere else
2. the amalgsmation will offer the possibility of save money by cutting the political costs and the burocracy costs and making the administration more efficient.
3. with or without the amalgamation, the important thing that is at the practical level, nothing will change. For example the offices should stay where they are.
4. the new municipality will be politically more powerful in front of other municipalities like Bologna metropolitan. In this way our interests will be protected outside our municiplity.
5. the fusion is an innovative process that will make as an example to follow for italy and the rest of europe.
6. the fusion seem to me another way to change everything to change nothing
7. it is not possible to say yes or not to the amalgamation without knowing how it will be, how much will it cost and how it will be done.
8. the fusion is a samll step to complete a path of amalgamation that started 20 years ago. The amalgamated municipality it is a realty in facts. How much do we have to wait still?
9. the amalgamation will erease the local diversities
10. the choice of the fusion is due to the wish of certain political parties to maintain the political dominance
11. the fusion is a decision that has already been taken and they are trying to imposing it top down. They are trying to sell the product "amalgamated municipality"
12. there are not enoughf elements do decide in favor or against the fusion
13. the fusion is the right answer to the limit of the union
14. it is not worth to make the amalgamation in this time of reorganization with the metropolitan bologna
15. through the fusion we will be able to derogare il patto di stabilita' and therefore unblock some founds. The latter can be invested in the municipalities that are more in need 
16. if the administration chose for the fusion it means that it is the right choice. This choice should be taken by the experts not the citizens
17. the shift from the union to the fusion is a step to big which brings too many uncertainties. If things are done more gradually the change will be hurtless because people will be already used to it.
18. in this fusion there is no project, no vision and nos trategy. Things should be done in a very different way.
19. the fusion will bring the resources to make the intervention that our territory needs, like the bycicle paths or the public transport between the municipalities or the high school.
20. it is not necessary to be big to be good. The small municipalities can be better managed of the bigger and do more things. It is a matter of good administration.
21. it is not yet clear how are they are going to amalgamate the contracts of the municipal clerks across the territory. things like these should be decided before the amalgamtion.
22. the amalgamation will benefit the emplyees and the citizens. The emplyees will increase their competences through more trainings. Therefore the citizens will benefit of more specialized professionals.
23. I would not like that the money of my taxes would be used in the municiplities next to mine
24. through the fusion we will be able to exploit the potentials of the territory to improve the building-, commercial- handcraft- and agricoltural development.
25. the fusion benefits the bigger mnicipalities at the detriment of the smalles also with respect to the external fundings.
26. the fusion is too risky because is a oneway process
27. if the fusion will not be done, the single municipalities will not be capable of maintaining the current quality of the services.
28. the union is a failure and a cost, because it absorbed just a very small part of the services and the money
29. we are misusing the fusion. The needs of the territory are not being respected and the valsmaoggia is being used as a labrat
30. in this days of crisis and changes at the european level, the amalgamation is necessary and opportune.
31. the fusion is not the only solution to the issues of our territory but it is the more concrete
32. with the amalgamation there will be a deficit of democracy because the municipalities will be only consultive. The citizens will have no power
33. the fusion is a leap in the unknown
34. the needs of the citizens are too different acros the municipalities. It will be too difficult for The amalgameted municipality to answer to everybody.
35. the consequence of the fusion is that either we will pay more than before or they will cut the services
36. the fusion is necessary to lower the taxes

## [Considerations]:
1. Jobs and growth in Townsville should be prioritised over Great Barrier Reef protection.
2. We don't need to worry too much about environmental damage in the Great Barrier Reef because future generations will be better able to deal with these problems than we are.
3. Protection of the Great Barrier Reef is worthwhile at whatever cost.
4. Government should provide funding support for industry, including mining projects such as the Adani mine.
5. Deep-pocketed green groups are willing to sacrifice our local economy for their own goals. 
6. It is not possible to conserve the reef over the long term without addressing climate change 
7. Economic development associated with mining will provide more opportunities for future generations in North Queensland.
8. The Great Barrier Reef is a great asset for the economy of this region and we should prioritise protecting it.
9. Mining development in Australia is a risk to the environment.
10. Climate change is an immediate threat requiring action.
11. Australia's contribution to global greenhouse gas emissions is so small that we should wait for other countries to take action on climate change before we do. 
12. There are more jobs to lose from Great Barrier Reef tourism than to be gained from the coal industry.
13. Government should be doing more to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
14. While job creation is important, we should prioritise industries that have less impact on the reef over those that have greater impact on the reef. 
15. There is no strong scientific evidence to suggest that the Great Barrier Reef is under threat from climate change.
16. Each new Australian coal mine will contribute greenhouse emissions that exacerbate the risk of climate change, and impacts to the Reef.
17. Coal-generated electricity must be phased out if we are to avoid catastrophic impacts of global warming, including the loss of the Great Barrier Reef.
18. If future generations could have their say about the Great Barrier Reef, they would be less concerned about the environmental impacts than many people make out.
19. We should prioritise protecting the environment in Townsville, even if it hurts our economy.
20. The first priority should be reducing other pressures on the reef (such as agricultural runoff or coastal development) so that the reef will be more resilient to climate change impacts. 
21. If we are serious about maintaining and improving people's living standards in Townsville, we need to make the most out of coal exports.
22. Climate change impacts on the Great Barrier Reef aren't something I'm worried about.
23. I think enough is being done to effectively manage the Great Barrier Reef.
24. We should prioritise economic development and job creation in Townsville over the environment. 
25. More scientific research is needed before we can say if climate change is a threat to the Great Barrier Reef.
26. Short term development thinking will ultimately lead to longer term reef damage and economic impacts.
27. The negative publicity about climate change impacts on the reef has negatively affected the local tourism industry.
28. If we don't take steps to protect the Great Barrier Reef future generations will miss out on the opportunity to experience the reef.
29. The mining industry provides thousands of jobs. Without it unemployment would have skyrocketed in regional Queensland.
30. A few self-interested politicians and influential companies are prepared to sacrifice our well-being for their own short-term gain.
31. There is no point throwing money at protecting the reef if our other actions contribute to its continuing decline.
32. I feel that future generations have been adequately considered in the management of the Great Barrier Reef.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. As a society, we have an obligation to help strengthen coming generations by eradicating diseases.
2. I would be OK with having my own genome edited.
3. Beacause of our changing environments, I believe that future humans will need genome editing to survive.
4. Genome editing technologies gives us power over human life itself.
5. It's a slippery slope from genome editing for medical reasons to using it for other reasons.
6. Genome editing is really cool science.
7. The idea of editing the human genome is scary.
8. It is better to accept our genes the way they are than to tamper with things we don't understand.
9. I am concerned that the use of human genome editing will advantage one group over another.
10. Suggesting genome editing will 'cure' disability diminishes those living with genetic conditions who need support.
11. I'm worried that human genome editing will widen the gap between those who can afford it and those who can't.
12. I worry that something will go wrong with genome technology.
13. Parents and guardians have a right to edit the genes of their children before they are born.
14. It's better to use genome editing to prevent a serious disease from happening rather than having to treat it with conventional medicine after it has occurred.
15. I think it's okay to use genome editing to change someone's appearance.
16. I don't think we know enough about genetic diseases or the long term consequences of genome editing
17. My concern is that as we start to tinker with the human genome, we're going to accidentally introduce a whole host of other problems.
18. I think we should keep an open mind about new discoveries.
19. I have a more positive feeling about gene editing in humans than I do for animals or plants.
20. If genome editing is proven to be safe, then I see no reason to oppose it.
21. There is nothing wrong with using genome editing to speed up evolution and help living things (including humans) adapt to challenges.
22. If human genome editing is available then it should be available to everyone who needs it, not just those who can afford it.
23. We find strength when we face illness and adversity. It makes us who we are. 
24. Interfering in people's genes is intervening a bit too far in human creation.
25. Editing genes that will be inherited is problematic because it means making decisions for future people who don't exist yet. 
26. Each individual has a right to decide for themselves whether to undergo gene editing, as long as the changes cannot be passed on to future generations.
27. When you change someone's genes you are fundamentally changing who they are.
28. Anything that's been artificially created in a lab gives me Frankenstein vibes.
29. The idea that people with genetic conditions might get cured in my lifetime is miraculous and incredible.
30. I think it would be amazing to have a choice in the way someone behaves.
31. If human genome editing can be used to make changes to humans on demand for any reason, the future will be like a dystopian movie.
32. The use of gene editing for non-medical reasons reminds me of the Nazis during the Second World War.
33. If we open the box of genome editing we will not know where to draw the line.
34. Genome editing in agriculture will have the biggest impact on people's health. 
35. The idea that genome editing can make perfect people and societies is extremely dangerous.
36. I'm concerned that genome editing will be used as a quick techno-fix without actually dealing with real problems.
37. Science and technology have too much control over our lives.

6. Less government regulation in health insurance would allow for more competitive pricing.
7. Health insurance costs should be income-based to make them more affordable for lower-income individuals.
8. Switzerland currently has a 'two-tier' healthcare system, where wealthier individuals receive better healthcare than others.
9. Income-based health insurance contributions would make insurance fairer for low-income individuals.
10. The Swiss healthcare system focuses too much on treating diseases rather than on disease prevention to improve public health.
11. A more centralized healthcare system, such as national hospital planning, would better organize and improve efficiency in healthcare.
12. More competition in mandatory health insurance, where insurers can offer alternative models, would promote innovation and efficiency in healthcare.
13. As health insurance premiums rise, more households require financial assistance, such as individual premium subsidies, to afford coverage.
14. It is important to involve more private actors in healthcare (e.g., outsourcing administrative tasks in hospitals to specialized companies) to reduce costs.
15. Higher tax deductions for medical expenses would help households manage healthcare costs more effectively.
16. Reducing the scope of mandatory health insurance coverage could help lower overall healthcare costs.
17. A more transparent healthcare system would help people understand costs and make better decisions.
18. The current system encourages excessive use of services once the deductible ('franchise') has been paid, leading to unnecessary treatments and higher overall costs.
19. Hospitals are more interested in maximizing their profits than in ensuring quality and access to healthcare.
20. A lack of financial support for preventive measures leads to higher healthcare costs in the long run.
21. More competition among insurance providers would lead to lower prices and better services.
22. The increasing demand for healthcare services is mainly due to an aging population that requires more medical care.
23. Abolishing mandatory health insurance would reduce the financial burden on households.
24. A public single-payer health insurance system would reduce administrative and marketing costs, making the healthcare system more affordable overall.

- In your response, return an ordered list of 24 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 24 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Reducing the scope of mandatory health insurance coverage could help lower overall healthcare costs.
2. Hospitals are more interested in maximizing their profits than in ensuring quality and access to healthcare.
3. Reducing bureaucratic inefficiencies and simplifying administrative processes in healthcare could lead to significant cost savings.
4. More competition among insurance providers would lead to lower prices and better services.
5. Government control of drug prices would prevent pharmaceutical companies from charging excessive prices.
6. Higher tax deductions for medical expenses would help households manage healthcare costs more effectively.
7. A more transparent healthcare system would help people understand costs and make better decisions.
8. It is important to involve more private actors in healthcare (e.g., outsourcing administrative tasks in hospitals to specialized companies) to reduce costs.
9. Income-based health insurance contributions would make insurance fairer for low-income individuals.
10. As health insurance premiums rise, more households require financial assistance, such as individual premium subsidies, to afford coverage.
11. A public single-payer health insurance system would reduce administrative and marketing costs, making the healthcare system more affordable overall.
12. Abolishing mandatory health insurance would reduce the financial burden on households.
13. Health insurance costs should be income-based to make them more affordable for lower-income individuals.
14. Better coordination between primary care, hospitals, and specialists is essential for the effective treatment of chronic diseases.
15. The Swiss healthcare system focuses too much on treating diseases rather than on disease prevention to improve public health.
16. Less government regulation in health insurance would allow for more competitive pricing.
17. Limiting the influence of private insurance companies in the Swiss healthcare system would help avoid higher costs without improving the quality of care.
18. A more centralized healthcare system, such as national hospital planning, would better organize and improve efficiency in healthcare.
19. The current system encourages excessive use of services once the deductible ('franchise') has been paid, leading to unnecessary treatments and higher overall costs.
20. A lack of financial support for preventive measures leads to higher healthcare costs in the long run.
21. Higher out-of-pocket payments would prevent excessive use of healthcare services.
22. Switzerland currently has a 'two-tier' healthcare system, where wealthier individuals receive better healthcare than others.
23. The increasing demand for healthcare services is mainly due to an aging population that requires more medical care.
24. More competition in mandatory health insurance, where insurers can offer alternative models, would promote innovation and efficiency in healthcare.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 6 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 6, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 6 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 6 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 6 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Encouraging more personal responsibility by abolishing mandatory health insurance and increasing out-of-pocket payments.
2. Less government regulation and more private competition would make healthcare more efficient and cost-effective.
3. More government control over pricing and greater financial support (e.g., individual premium subsidies) would help those in need.
4. A universal, public, and unified healthcare system, where people pay according to their income, would ensure healthcare access for everyone.
5. Fixing financial inefficiencies in the healthcare system could save a lot of money without major changes to the system.
6. No changes are needed to the current healthcare system, as it functions well as it is.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Favor universal healthcare based on income, efficiency improvements, and oppose abolishing mandatory insurance.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 49 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 49 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 49 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. The community that provides samples for research should receive improved medical services in return.
2. Genetic studies of race on ethnic or cultural groups will lead to the discrimination of those groups.
3. People with a [chronic disease or] genetic condition in their family have a responsibility to be involved in genetic research.
4. It is always acceptable to do research on samples that identify me, without my prior permission.
5. There must be special consideration of the views of Aboriginal people towards healthcare and genetic research.
6. People who provide samples should be active in the set up and ongoing management of biobanks.
7. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
8. People should be told if commercial companies could get access to their samples and information.
9. We should all provide samples to biobanks because it will benefit everyone.
10. People who provide samples for research should get special access to the treatments that result from this research.
11. I trust researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
12. There is no point asking the public for their views on the ethical issues in science and technology.
13. Genetic studies will lead to the discrimination of people living with genetic conditions or disabilities.
14. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
15. Commercial companies should get access to biobanks, otherwise new drugs and treatments will not be developed.
16. Biobanks will only lead to high profits and expensive treatments that most people can't afford.
17. I trust biobanks with managers who are independent of researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
18. People should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at any time.
19. It is acceptable for samples and information that doesn't identify me to be sent to researchers overseas.
20. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies
21. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.
22. Biobanks are valuable even if they only advance science (e.g. provide new information about diseases) and do not lead to treatments or cures.
23. Profits from biobanking should be shared in some way with the community who provided the samples.
24. I trust independent research ethics committees, which are not connected to the biobank in anyway, to decide whether research is ethical and approve who gets access to my samples.
25. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health in other ways.
26. I do not mind if my sample is connected to my name and medical information.
27. Policy makers need to consider whether WA should not have biobanks.
28. There is no risk to the people who provide samples and information to biobanks.
29. I do not mind if researchers have access to my samples, when there is no way I can be identified.
30. Commercial companies should keep all the profits they make from biobanking because they take the financial risks and put up the money to develop new drugs and treatments.
31. The public will be more protected if biobanks are government-funded not privately funded.
32. Information about people's genes and the traits they inherit from their parents is more private than their medical records.
33. Biobanks are valuable because they promise huge benefits for our economy.
34. I should be asked for my permission every time researchers want to use my samples for research
35. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government.
36. Collecting samples from people in an ethnic or cultural group is acceptable only if the whole group has agreed to participate.
37. Biobanks need to be monitored and reviewed by external, independent people to prevent the misuse of data and samples.
38. The biobank owner should be able to sell any information they have about my genes, if they want to.
39. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for in the future bothers me.
40. Improved health is more likely to come from educating people about their diet and lifestyle than from biobanks.
41. Genetic research will improve our lives.
42. People should be paid for providing their samples to a biobank.
43. I don't mind if my samples are connected to my medical records without my prior permission, so long as researchers don't get access to any data that identifies me.
44. Researchers and institutions (e.g. hospitals and universities) should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.
45. Religious groups need to be asked for their views about biobanks and genetic research.
46. The priorities for health should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
47. It's OK if data that identifies me is stored in a separate database and replaced in the biobank by a unique non-identifying code.
48. My sample should never be permanently anonymized since I should be contacted about important research results
49. I should have property rights to my tissues before and after they leave my body

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Privately Funded with minimal regulation: Minimal regulation of privately run biobanking system with maximum participation of the public. Low privacy provisions.
2. Minimal Government Input: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Fairly relaxed oversight of use of biobanks and  privacy provisions (low level of regulation).
3. Publicly Funded with minimal regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
4. Privately Funded with strong regulation: A BB system where funding is provided mostly by private companies, withstrong government oversight and privacy provisions.
5. Cautious Implementation: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Very strict oversight of use of biobanks and strong privacy provisions.
6. Publicly Funded with strong regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
7. High Privacy: Implementation of a (publicy or privately owned) biobanking system where privacy of individuals is paramount. Stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individual donors.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritized strong regulation and government oversight for privacy and ethical management.

## [Policies]:
1. Privately Funded with strong regulation: A BB system where funding is provided mostly by private companies, withstrong government oversight and privacy provisions.
2. Publicly Funded with minimal regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
3. Minimal Government Input: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Fairly relaxed oversight of use of biobanks and  privacy provisions (low level of regulation).
4. Publicly Funded with strong regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
5. High Privacy: Implementation of a (publicy or privately owned) biobanking system where privacy of individuals is paramount. Stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individual donors.
6. Privately Funded with minimal regulation: Minimal regulation of privately run biobanking system with maximum participation of the public. Low privacy provisions.
7. Cautious Implementation: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Very strict oversight of use of biobanks and strong privacy provisions.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Favored strong regulation and privacy, less support for minimal oversight and private funding.
